for editors of the NEWS-LETTER to
to say a few words of welcome and of
greeting. Suffice it to say, that the
NEWS-LETTER does extend its
heartiest greetings to new students
and usher them good fortune and success during their residence at the
University.

said. No first issue of the NEWSLETTER is complete without a word

"college spirit."

The News-Letter is going to take
an editorial stand in the present presidential campaign!
In a few days, this paper—for the
first time in its 39 years of history—
will definitely align itself in a political campaign; it will advocate the
election of a president editorially;
and it will continue in its presentation
of facts and principles until the day
of election.
The times demand it! No, not the
times but the issues involved, which
are, after all, so closely associated
with the times. Never before has the
college student been so profoundly
affected by a presidential election.
Never before have the issues involved
in a national election been so vital
to the college student as well as to the
"man on the street."
Until a few years ago the college
student was a members of a separate
and distinct class—set off from the
world by all the tradition of academic

Students are definitely interested in
national affairs. They must be—because it touches them personally and
immediately, as it touches any other
person.
The election of 1936, far from being
just another election, is of special,
even paramount importance. From
every point of view, this one is a
climatic election; from every point
of view, this election marks a crisis
in American history. Students, who in
all to short a time will inherit that
America, cannot neglect to realize
the importance of the issues at stake,
the importance of the outcome of the
election, the effect of that election on
their own future. This election represents the struggle to save America
temporarily at least, perhaps permanently, for Democracy.
Four years ago, the News-Letter
sponsored a straw vote. Herbert Hoover won by a slight plurality. About the
third week in October, this paper will
conduct another straw vote among
both faculty and students. Until that
time, the columns of the News-Letter
will be entirely thrown open to student discussion. The paper will express itself freely. It is hoped that
the student body will do the same.
Democracy is based on education,
and education is based, ultimately,
on free and fearless discussion.
During the next week, in the next
two issues of the News-Letter, the
policy of the paper will be definitely
outlined; selection and rejections for
the presidency will be made; the issues of the election will be clarified;
and the question of the future of
Democracy will be placed squarely before the students.
The News-Letter believes in a democracy, both political and economic.
The News-Letter believes that, in the
course of events, the future of this
democracy has been gravely imperiled. The News-Letter is convinced
that the question of Democracy's future is the primary issue of the
1336 election. And, because the NewsLetter considers that issue of paramount importance, it will attempt to
take a rational but unequivocal position in the election campaign—a position based upon unbiased, unprejudiced facts.

"When war is declared, truth is the
first casualty," goes the classic adage.
Falsehood in War-Time is a more than
commendable discussion and exposition of the numerous lies, frauds and
deceptions to which the war-generation was submitted in a monstrous attempt to arouse its passion and indignation.
The reprinting of this volume comes
at a most fortuitous moment. Today
the tenseness and double-dealings of
international rivalry have resulted in
the exaltation of patriotism over
truth as the essential element and
virtue of statesmanship. The chances
are very great that the world will
shortly find itself in the chaos of
another great War. When that war
comes, one of its chief weapons will
be falsehood, and lying. The casual,
everyday lie is often condoned, or at
least ignored. But the wholesale deception of an entire nation by official
connivance cannot be easily neglected.
Lord Ponsonby has collected in his
small volume a group of the more
common, more insidious lies circulated in England, France, Germany,
Italy, and America during the War.
A long career in parliament and the
diplomatic service has given him
both the means and the ability to
trace these lies to their sources.
The denial of England's commitments to France, the invasion of
Belgium as the causus belli, the war
guilt of Germany, the passage of
Russian troops through England, the
stories of the mutilated nurse, the
handless baby, the crucified Canadian,
and the German corpse factory are
objectively, calmly, but relentlessly
traced by Lord Ponsonby to their
origins and exposed as deliberate subterfuge and trickery on the part of
supposedly responsible governments.
"There is not a living soul in any
country who does not deeply resent having his passions roused,
his indignation flamed, his pariotism exploited, and his highest
ideals desecrated by concealment,
subterfuge, fraud, trickery, and
deliberate lying on the part of
those in whom he is taught to
repose confidence and to whom
